questions.text: A patient with bloody diarrhea. Flask-shaped ulcers seen. Infection due to ingestion of quadrinucleate cysts. What is the appropriate treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Metronidazole

 

The patient presents with bloody diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers, which are indicative of intestinal amoebiasis caused by Entamoeba histolytica. This parasitic infection results from the ingestion of cysts (quadrinucleate form) of the organism, which then invade the intestinal wall causing characteristic flask-shaped ulcers.

 

 

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating amoebiasis because it effectively eradicates both the trophozoite form in the intestines and the cyst form in the liver or other tissues. It works by disrupting the DNA of the parasites, leading to their death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albendazole: Albendazole is an anti-parasitic drug used to treat infections caused by worms, such as roundworm, hookworm, and tapeworm. It is not effective against Entamoeba histolytica.

 

Option B. Mebendazole: Mebendazole is another anti-helminthic medication, used primarily to treat worm infections. It does not have activity against protozoan infections like amoebiasis.

 

Option D. Chloroquine: Chloroquine is primarily used to treat malaria and certain autoimmune conditions. It is not effective against Entamoeba histolytica infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient presenting with bloody diarrhea and flask-shaped ulcers caused by Entamoeba histolytica, the appropriate treatment is Metronidazole. This medication is effective against the invasive trophozoite stage of the parasite.

choices.text: Antigen detection in the stool sample

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory test is used to diagnose rotavirus diarrhea? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antigen detection in the stool sample

 

Rotavirus is among the most common identifiable viral causes of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years. Most cases are asymptomatic or present with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance.

 

Diagnosis – ELISA – Detects rotavirus antigen in Stool

 

  • Molecular methods – PCR, BioFilm Array

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antigen detection in blood: Not used for rotavirus as the virus does not typically present in blood.

 

Option C. Antibody detection in serum: This method is not typically used for acute diagnosis as it indicates past exposure rather than current infection.

 

Option D. Light microscopy of stool specimen: This is ineffective for viruses like rotavirus due to their small size and lack of distinctive morphology in light microscopy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antigen detection in stool samples is the standard diagnostic approach for confirming rotavirus infection, crucial for implementing appropriate management strategies, especially in managing dehydration risks in young children.

questions.text: The average daily dietary nutrient intake level sufficient to meet the nutrient requirements of nearly all (97-98%) healthy individuals in a particular life stage and gender group is known as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Recommended dietary allowance

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population. RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population. RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adequate intake: A value based on observed or experimentally determined approximations of nutrient intake by a group (or groups) of healthy people.

 

Option B. Dietary goals: are quantitative national targets for selected macronutrients and micronutrients aimed at preventing long-term chronic disease. They focus on population-level nutritional health.

 

Option C. The estimated average requirement (EAR): Average daily level of intake estimated to meet the requirements of 50% of healthy individual’s RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA)

 

  • Definition: RDA is a level of intake corresponding to Mean + 2 Standard Deviation, which covers requirement of 97.5% of population
  • RDA is safe level of intake which is likely to be inadequate in not more than 2.5% population
  • RDA is decided by a panel of experts and is based on scientific research
  • RDA is often higher than the recommended minimum requirement: RDA includes both daily requirement and some additional requirement for periods of growth or illness
  • RDA is based on Estimated Average Requirement
  • RDA ‘safe level approach’ is not used for energy since excess energy intake is undesirable.
  • For energy: only mean or average requirement is defined as RDA.

choices.text: Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament

questions.text: In which of the following meniscal tears will meniscectomy be a more suitable option than meniscal repair? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Tears in the inner zone

 

Meniscal tears in the inner zone (inner 2/3rd) are treated by excision (meniscectomy) rather than repair. This is because the inner 2/3rd of the meniscus is avascular, which means it has poor healing potential. In contrast, the peripheral 1/3rd of the meniscus receives blood supply and therefore can be repaired when torn since it has better healing potential.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tears in the outer zone - This is incorrect because the outer zone (peripheral 1/3rd) is vascular and has good healing potential, making it suitable for meniscal repair rather than meniscectomy.

 

Option B. Tears in the middle zone - This is partially incorrect. While the middle zone has less vascularity than the outer zone, tears at the junction of the middle and outer zones may still be amenable to repair depending on specific characteristics of the tear.

 

Option D. Tears at the junction of the anterior horn of the medial meniscus & tibial collateral ligament - This is incorrect because this area is in the peripheral region of the meniscus which receives adequate blood supply, making repair a more suitable option than meniscectomy.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Meniscectomy is preferred for tears in the inner avascular 2/3rd of the meniscus due to poor healing potential, while tears in the vascular peripheral 1/3rd are better treated with repair.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency and is found to have raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis. The mother reports that she saw her consuming a substance in an unknown dose. What is the likely substance? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

  

The patient presents with symptoms of sympathetic overactivity, including raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis (excessive sweating), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These symptoms are characteristic of stimulant intoxication, particularly with substances that increase the release of catecholamines, such as cocaine. Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that induces a surge of dopamine, leading to intense sympathetic activation, which matches the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that causes respiratory and cardiovascular depression, pinpoint pupils (miosis), and reduced sympathetic activity, which is the opposite of what is observed in this case.

 

Option C. Heroin: Like morphine, heroin is an opioid that results in symptoms of sedation, respiratory depression, and miosis, rather than the sympathetic overdrive seen here.

 

Option D. Chlordiazepoxide: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that acts as a sedative and anxiolytic. It would typically cause sedation, hypotension, and muscle relaxation, not the heightened sympathetic response observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication is associated with signs of sympathetic overactivity, including elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis.

questions.text: A child was brought to the OPD complaining of swelling in the neck region, which moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. Which of the following is the correct treatment? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sistrunk procedure

 

The clinical presentation of a neck swelling that moves with deglutition (swallowing) and protrusion of the tongue is highly suggestive of a thyroglossal duct cyst. This congenital anomaly arises from remnants of the thyroglossal duct, which can form cysts anywhere along the duct's path from the base of the tongue to the thyroid gland.

 

The definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, whether it is inflamed, ruptured, or has formed a fistula, is the Sistrunk procedure. This surgical procedure involves the removal of the cyst along with the entire thyroglossal tract and a portion of the hyoid bone to prevent recurrence.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antibiotics: While antibiotics may be necessary if there is an infection, they do not treat the underlying cyst and would not prevent recurrence.

 

Option C. Incision and drainage: This approach may be used if there is an abscess formation, but it is not definitive treatment and would not prevent recurrence of the cyst or fistula.

 

Option D. Excision: Simple excision of the cyst alone is not sufficient as it does not remove the entire thyroglossal tract or part of the hyoid bone, leading to a high risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Sistrunk procedure is the definitive treatment for a thyroglossal duct cyst, involving the excision of the cyst, the entire thyroglossal tract, and part of the hyoid bone to ensure complete removal and prevent recurrence.

questions.text: Which of the following is accumulated in joint in the mucopolysaccharidosis associated with Natowicz disease? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hyaluronic acid

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by:

 

  • Enzyme deficiency: Hyaluronidase
  • Accumulated substance: Hyaluronic acid
  • Clinical features include joint pain and short stature
  • This is a rare form of mucopolysaccharidosis
  • The condition results from inability to break down hyaluronic acid due to hyaluronidase deficiency

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dermatan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because dermatan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and VI
  • Its accumulation typically leads to cardiovascular manifestations like atherosclerosis

 

Option B. Heparan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because heparan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS types I, II and III
  • Its accumulation typically leads to mental retardation
  • Present on cell surfaces and has a role in cell-cell adhesion

 

Option C. Keratan sulfate: Incorrect

 

  • Because keratan sulfate accumulation is seen in MPS type IV
  • It is unique among GAGs as it does not contain uronic acid
  • Responsible for corneal transparency
  • Present in cornea and connective tissue

 

Educational Objective:

 

Natowicz disease (MPS type IX) is characterized by hyaluronidase deficiency leading to accumulation of hyaluronic acid in joints, causing joint pain and short stature.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the electrolyte composition of 'ReSoMal' oral rehydration salts solution used for malnourished children? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Sodium 65 mmol/L

 

Explanation:

 

ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition) is specifically formulated for rehydrating children with severe acute malnutrition (SAM). The sodium content in ReSoMal is 45 mmol/L, not 65 mmol/L as stated in option C. This reduced sodium concentration is intentional because malnourished children have excess body sodium despite presenting with low serum sodium levels. The standard WHO ORS contains 90 mmol/L sodium, which is too high for malnourished children.

 

The correct composition of ReSoMal includes:

  • Sodium: 45 mmol/L
  • Potassium: 40 mmol/L
  • Chloride: 70 mmol/L
  • Glucose: 125 mmol/L
  • Magnesium: 3 mmol/L
  • Zinc: 0.3 mmol/L
  • Copper: 0.045 mmol/L

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper 0.045 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains copper at a concentration of 0.045 mmol/L, which helps address micronutrient deficiencies common in malnourished children.

 

Option B. Potassium 40 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal has increased potassium (40 mmol/L) compared to standard ORS (20 mmol/L) to address potassium depletion in malnourished children.

 

Option D. Magnesium 3 mmol/L - Correct. ReSoMal contains magnesium at 3 mmol/L to help correct magnesium deficiency commonly seen in severe malnutrition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ReSoMal has a lower sodium concentration (45 mmol/L) and higher potassium concentration (40 mmol/L) than standard ORS to address the specific electrolyte abnormalities in severe acute malnutrition. This specialized formulation helps prevent complications like heart failure during rehydration therapy in malnourished children.

choices.text: EMLA means equal mixture of LA
Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream
1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding this? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Methemoglobinemia is a complication of this cream 

 

The cream shown in the image is EMLA cream, which is a topical anesthetic. EMLA cream contains a combination of two local anesthetics, lidocaine and prilocaine, in a 1:1 ratio. One of the known complications of EMLA cream is methemoglobinemia. This condition can occur, especially when the cream is used in large quantities or in patients with certain predispositions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. EMLA means equal mixture of LA: EMLA means Eutectic mixture of LA and not equal mixture of LA.

 

Option B. It contains lignocaine and ropivacaine: This option is incorrect because EMLA cream does not contain ropivacaine. The active ingredients in EMLA cream are lidocaine (lignocaine) and prilocaine.

 

Option D. 1 gm of 5% cream contains lignocaine 50mg: This option is also incorrect. 1 gram of EMLA 5% cream contains 25mg of lidocaine and 25mg of prilocaine, not 50mg of lidocaine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

EMLA cream can cause methemoglobinemia as a complication, especially when used inappropriately or in large quantities.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented to the casualty with confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements. What could be the vitamin deficiency seen in this patient?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B deficiency

 

Vitamin B deficiency: This is the correct answer. The symptoms given in question are suggestive of Wernicke encephalopathy, which is caused by vitamin B1 (Thiamine) deficiency. Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is caused by a deficiency in vitamin B1 (thiamine). Chronic alcoholism can lead to thiamine deficiency, which results in neurological symptoms like those described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A deficiency: Vitamin A deficiency typically presents with different symptoms, such as night blindness and skin issues, and is not related to the neurological symptoms seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome.

 

Option C. Vitamin D deficiency: Vitamin D deficiency can lead to various bone related problems like Rickets and Osteomalacia, but it is not associated with the specific symptoms of confusion, ataxia, and painful eye movements seen in this case.

 

Option D. Vitamin C deficiency: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, primarily presents with symptoms like fatigue, joint pain, and bleeding gums. It is not related to the neurological symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wernicke encephalopathy – An acute, reversible but life-threatening condition. Clinical Vignette include Confusion, Ophthalmoplegia, Nystagmus, Ataxia.

questions.text: A patient present with an X-ray showing cardiomegaly, along with symptoms of hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, and "floppy baby" syndrome. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pompe's disease


Pompe's disease, also known as Type II glycogen storage disease, is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme acid maltase (also known as alpha-glucosidase). This enzyme is responsible for breaking down glycogen in the lysosomes. Without this enzyme, glycogen accumulates within the lysosomes, leading to lysosomal storage disease. The clinical features of Pompe's disease include cardiomegaly, hypotonia, hepatomegaly, macroglossia, and the characteristic "floppy baby" syndrome due to severe muscle weakness. The disease primarily affects the heart and skeletal muscles, often leading to heart failure as seen in the presented X-ray with cardiomegaly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ebstein anomaly: This is a congenital heart defect involving the tricuspid valve but does not present with hypotonia, macroglossia, hepatomegaly, or the "floppy baby" syndrome seen in Pompe's disease. Ebstein anomaly primarily affects the heart, causing cyanosis and heart failure but lacks the systemic metabolic features of Pompe's.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is another congenital heart defect characterized by the abnormal arrangement of the heart's major arteries. While it presents with severe cardiopulmonary symptoms such as cyanosis and heart failure, it does not cause hypotonia, macroglossia, or hepatomegaly, distinguishing it from Pompe's disease.

 

Option D.  Von Gierke's disease: Von Gierke's disease (Type I glycogen storage disease) affects liver metabolism, leading to severe fasting hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, renomegaly, and metabolic derangements such as lactic acidosis and hyperuricemia. However, it does not involve cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, or "floppy baby" syndrome, making it an incorrect diagnosis in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Pompe's disease is characterized by the combination of cardiomegaly, muscle hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and macroglossia, often presenting as "floppy baby" syndrome due to lysosomal storage of glycogen.

questions.text: A young girl has been experiencing repeated instances of yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was only 3 months old. Given her immune system's condition, which of the listed vaccines should not be administered to her? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Measles/MMR

 

Based on the information provided, the girl child has a history of recurrent yeast infections and respiratory virus infections since she was 3 months old. This suggests that she may have an underlying immunodeficiency.

 

In this scenario, the measles/MMR vaccine would be contraindicated due to the risk of causing a severe infection in an immunocompromised individual.

 

CONTRAINDICATIONS OF LIVE VACCINES –

 

  • Immunodeficient individuals (Symptomatic HIV infection) except BCG vaccine
  • Immunosuppressed individuals (patient with leukemia or patients on antimetabolites, steroids or radiation)
  • Pregnancy (except Yellow fever)

 

Additional Information

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Killed IPV (Inactivated Polio Vaccine): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it does not contain live virus.

 

Option C. DPT (Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Option D. TT/Td (Tetanus Toxoid/Tetanus and Diphtheria): Safe for immunocompromised individuals as it is not a live vaccine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Live vaccines like Measles/MMR should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals due to the risk of severe infection. Instead, inactivated or subunit vaccines, which do not contain live pathogens, should be used.

questions.text: A 4-week-old child was brought to the emergency with recurrent episodes of non-bilious vomiting. He was dehydrated. What should be corrected before performing surgical treatment in this baby? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hypokalemia

 

The child presents with recurrent non-bilious vomiting, which is a classic sign of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS). IHPS is a condition in infants causing severe vomiting due to the thickening of the pylorus muscle, leading to obstruction.

 

Patients with IHPS often develop a specific electrolyte imbalance characterized by hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The vomiting leads to a loss of gastric acid (hydrochloric acid), resulting in low chloride levels and secondary metabolic alkalosis. This condition also results in potassium loss, leading to hypokalemia.

 

Before performing surgical treatment (such as a pyloromyotomy, often referenced in this context as the Ramstedt procedure), it is crucial to correct the electrolyte imbalance to stabilize the patient. The primary focus is on correcting hypokalemia because potassium is essential for normal cellular function and cardiac rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperkalemia: This condition involves high potassium levels, which is not typically seen in patients with IHPS. Instead, these patients usually have low potassium levels due to vomiting.

 

Option C. Hyponatremia: While hyponatremia (low sodium levels) can occur, it is generally not as significant or immediately life-threatening as hypokalemia in the context of IHPS.

 

Option D. Hypernatremia: High sodium levels are not characteristic of IHPS. The vomiting associated with IHPS more commonly leads to losses of electrolytes like potassium and chloride, not an increase in sodium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (IHPS) is often associated with hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. Correction of hypokalemia is essential before surgical intervention.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and is diagnosed with endometrial hyperplasia without atypia based on an endometrial biopsy. What is the most appropriate treatment option for her? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Levonorgestrel Intrauterine System (LNG-IUS)

 

Endometrial hyperplasia without atypia is a premalignant condition caused by unopposed estrogen stimulation of the endometrium, leading to excessive proliferation of the endometrial glands. 

 

The primary concern with endometrial hyperplasia is its potential progression to endometrial carcinoma, though the risk is much lower in cases without atypia (approximately 1%).

 

LNG-IUS (Mirena) -progesterone is the mainstay treatment because it induces endometrial atrophy and prevents further proliferation.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. COCPs (Incorrect): Although Combined contraceptive pills are protective for endometrial cancer, they are not a treatment option for endometrial hyperplasia due to the estrogen component. 

 

Option C. Danazol (Incorrect): Danazol is an antigonadotropin with significant androgenic side effects. While it was historically used for endometriosis, it is not used for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Option D. Mifepristone (Incorrect): Mifepristone is primarily used for medical termination of pregnancy and occasionally for emergency contraception or fibroid treatment. It is not indicated for treating endometrial hyperplasia.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Remember that LNG-IUS is the preferred treatment for endometrial hyperplasia without atypia due to its local progesterone delivery, which causes endometrial atrophy. This condition has a lower risk of malignancy (~1%) compared to hyperplasia with atypia, which requires hysterectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a formal thought disorder? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Derailment

 

Formal thought disorders refer to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought, rather than the content of thought.

 

Here, the association between two successive thoughts is disturbed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Obsession: It refers to recurrent, intrusive, and unwanted thoughts. It's more related to possession than the form of thought.

 

Option C. Delusion: It is a false belief that is unshakeable and cannot be explained on the basis of a person's social and cultural background.It is a disorder of thought content.

 

Option D. Thought insertion: It is the belief that certain of one's thoughts are not one's own, but rather are inserted into one's mind. This is also a possession of thought, not its form.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Formal thought disorders pertain to abnormalities in the organization, associations and connections of the thought. Derailment, loose associations, neologisms are examples of a formal thought disorder.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 10

questions.text: MTP for failure of contraception can be done till: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 20 weeks

 

The correct answer is 20 weeks. According to the Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Amendment Act of 2021, termination of pregnancy for the failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks. The Act outlines specific requirements for performing an MTP at different stages of pregnancy:

 

  1. Up to 20 weeks: MTP can be done for various reasons, including maternal health risks, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, or failure of contraception. Only one doctor's opinion is required for termination within this period.
  2. 20 to 24 weeks: Requires the opinion of two doctors. The reasons include threats to maternal health, fetal anomalies, pregnancy resulting from rape, pregnancies in minors, changes in marital status (e.g., becoming a widow or divorce), humanitarian grounds (e.g., war, natural disasters), or if the woman is disabled.
  3. Beyond 24 weeks: Termination is only permitted for substantial fetal malformations and requires approval from a medical board due to the viability of the fetus at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the MTP Amendment Act of 2021, MTP for failure of contraception can be performed up to 20 weeks with the opinion of one doctor.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the auditory pathway? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: C. Genu of the internal capsule

 

The auditory pathway consists of multiple relays from the cochlea to the auditory cortex. The trapezoid body contains crossing fibers from the cochlear nuclei to the superior olivary nucleus. The lateral lemniscus carries auditory information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus. The medial geniculate body is the thalamic relay nucleus for auditory information before it reaches the auditory cortex. However, the genu of internal capsule contains corticobulbar fibers and not auditory fibers. Auditory radiations pass through the sublentiform part of the internal capsule, not the genu.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trapezoid body - This is part of the auditory pathway, containing crossing fibers from cochlear nuclei to superior olivary nucleus.

 

Option B. Medial geniculate body - This is a key relay station in the auditory pathway, located in the thalamus. It receives input from the inferior colliculus and projects to the auditory cortex.

 

Option D. Lateral lemniscus - This is an important auditory tract in the brainstem that carries information from the superior olivary nucleus to the inferior colliculus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The auditory pathway involves the trapezoid body, lateral lemniscus, inferior colliculus, and medial geniculate body before reaching the auditory cortex via the sublentiform (not genu) part of the internal capsule.

choices.text: Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli
Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance

questions.text: A 56-year-old man was diagnosed with COVID-19 and was put on mechanical ventilation. He passed away after a week. What is the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli

 

In a patient with severe COVID-19 who was on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem change seen in the lungs is, thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli.

 

COVID-19 is known to cause severe respiratory illness, and in severe cases, patients may require mechanical ventilation. One of the characteristic features of severe COVID-19 pneumonia is the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). ARDS is characterized by diffuse alveolar damage, including the accumulation of fibrin-rich hyaline membranes lining the alveolar walls. This can result in the formation of a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, leading to impaired gas exchange and respiratory failure.

 

While acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage, perivascular cuffing, and pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance may be seen in other respiratory diseases, they are not typically associated with severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acute and chronic alveolar hemorrhage: This may be seen in conditions like vasculitis or certain types of pneumonia but is not a hallmark of severe COVID-19.

 

Option C. Perivascular cuffing: This refers to lymphocytic infiltration around blood vessels and is more common in viral myocarditis and certain chronic lung diseases.

 

Option D. Pulmonary artery hypertrophy with increased resistance: This is typically associated with chronic pulmonary hypertension and not an immediate feature of severe COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with severe COVID-19, especially those who have been on mechanical ventilation, the likely post-mortem finding in the lungs is a thick layer of fibrin lining the alveoli, indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and severe diffuse alveolar damage.

questions.text: A diabetic truck driver presents to you with cough and breathlessness. A diagnosis of pneumonia was confirmed, and histopathological examination revealed dichotomous branching, as shown below. What is the likely causative agent?  (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspergillus

 

The most likely causative agent based on the clinical features and image showing dichotomous branching at acute angles given is Aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients. This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs. Voriconazole is the drug of choice.

 

Other manifestations include allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis where central bronchiectasis is usually seen. Aspergilloma and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

 

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain is used.

 

Other methods for diagnosis include detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black.

 

Yellow-green colonies are seen in case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores.

 

Invasive aspergillosis is treated with intravenous amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A and Option B. Rhizopus and Mucor are zygomycetes that are responsible for mucormycosis. Non-septate, broad hyphae are seen on tissue samples stained with hematoxylin and eosin.

 

The image below shows broad aseptate and irregularly-branched non-septate hyphae of Mucor.

 

 

Option C. Candida, the causative agent for candidiasis, appear as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Culture colonies are creamy-white and have a yeasty odor.

 

Candida albicans, the most commonly implicated pathogenic species, form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

 

The image below shows candidal hyphae and chlamydospores.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of respiratory infections in immunocompromised patients, the presence of dichotomous branching at acute angles in histopathological examination should prompt consideration of Aspergillus infection, necessitating prompt antifungal therapy to manage the potential for invasive disease.

questions.text: Identify the organism given below. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Microsporum


The image provided shows a hair shaft with white-colored structures inside, characteristic of endothrix infection, where the fungal elements are present within the hair shaft. Endothrix infections are typically caused by Trichophyton species such as Trichophyton tonsurans and Trichophyton violaceum. However, since these specific Trichophyton species are not listed as options, the Ans.  is determined by excluding the other choices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichosporon: This option is incorrect because Trichosporon is associated with white piedra, not endothrix infections. Trichosporon causes superficial infections that present as white nodules on hair shafts, which is distinct from the endothrix appearance.

 

Option B. Epidermophyton: Epidermophyton does not infect hair. It is known for infecting skin and nails but never the hair, which rules it out as the causative organism in this scenario where the infection is clearly within the hair shaft.

 

Option D. Candida: Candida typically causes mucocutaneous infections and is not involved in hair shaft infections, making it an unlikely candidate for the description provided.

 

Educational Objective:


Endothrix infections involve fungal elements within the hair shaft, commonly caused by specific Trichophyton species. In the absence of these species as answer options, the organism that affects hair (Microsporum) should be considered.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Tuberculosis of the Hip during the Stage of Synovitis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Apparent Lengthening

 

In the stage of synovitis (Stage I) of tuberculosis of the hip, there is effusion into the joint which demands the hip to be positioned for maximum capacity. This position is one of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Due to the pelvic tilt compensating for the abduction deformity, the pelvis tilts downwards on the affected side, which creates an apparent lengthening of the limb. However, when true limb lengths are measured, both limbs are equal. This stage is therefore also called the "stage of apparent lengthening" and lasts for a very short period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion, Abduction, Internal Rotation - This is incorrect because in Stage I (synovitis), the hip assumes a position of flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Internal rotation typically occurs in Stage II (arthritis) when muscle spasm develops.

 

Option B. Flexion, Adduction, External Rotation - This is incorrect because during synovitis, the position is flexion, abduction, and external rotation. Adduction deformity develops later in Stage II when articular cartilage involvement leads to muscle spasm.

 

Option D. True Shortening - This is incorrect for Stage I. True shortening occurs in Stage III (stage of erosion) when there is actual destruction of bone. In Stage I, there is apparent lengthening with equal true limb lengths.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

TB Hip Stage I (synovitis) presents with the hip in flexion, abduction, and external rotation, resulting in apparent lengthening due to downward pelvic tilt compensating for abduction deformity, while true limb lengths remain equal.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a rapidly growing, painless mass in her right breast that she first noticed about 3 months ago. On physical examination, the mass is well-circumscribed, lobulated, and larger than 5 cm in diameter. A history of a similar lesion occurred 2 years back also. A core needle biopsy is performed, and the histological examination reveals the image as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phyllodes tumor

 

Phyllodes tumor is a rare breast tumor that typically presents in middle-aged women (fourth to fifth decade). It is characterized by rapid growth, a lobulated appearance, and often exceeds 5 cm in diameter.

 

Phyllodes tumors can be distinguished from fibroadenomas by their stromal overgrowth and the presence of characteristic leaf-like projections seen in histological examinations. The image shows a stromal tumor with these classical leaf-like projections, confirming the diagnosis of Phyllodes tumor.

 

Phyllodes tumors can recur and have a low risk of becoming malignant, setting them apart from benign fibroadenomas and malignant carcinomas.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Invasive ductal carcinoma: This is the most common type of breast cancer, characterized by a solid mass with irregular borders. It typically presents with more aggressive features, such as lymphovascular invasion, which are absent in this case. The histology does not show the leaf-like stromal projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroadenoma: A common benign breast tumor seen mostly in younger women, characterized by a well-circumscribed, mobile mass. Histologically, it shows a mix of glandular and stromal elements but lacks the prominent stromal overgrowth and leaf-like projections seen in Phyllodes tumors.

 

Option D. Ductal papilloma: This benign tumor involves the breast ducts and often presents with nipple discharge rather than a large, rapidly growing mass. The histological appearance is distinct from that of Phyllodes tumors, lacking the stromal and leaf-like characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phyllodes tumors are rapidly growing, lobulated breast masses with characteristic leaf-like stromal projections on histology, commonly seen in middle-aged women, and may recur.

questions.text:
Which of the following best describes the ABG findings: (FMGE JULY 2024)

 

pH – 7.28,

PaCO2 – 28 mm Hg,

PaO2 – 98 mm Hg,

Na – 140 mEq/L,

K – 4.9 mEq/L,

HCO3 – 14 mEq/L,

Cl – 100 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Metabolic acidosis

 

The ABG (arterial blood gas) findings indicate a pH of 7.28, which is below the normal range (7.35-7.45), indicating acidosis. Both PaCO2 and HCO3 are low, which suggests a primary metabolic issue.

 

According to the mnemonic "ROME" (Respiratory Opposite, Metabolic Equal), in metabolic disorders, the pH and bicarbonate move in the same direction. Here, both pH and HCO3 are low, confirming metabolic acidosis.

 

Additionally, calculating the anion gap helps further classify the metabolic acidosis. The anion gap is calculated as Na - (HCO3 + Cl) = 140 - (14 + 100) = 26, which is above the normal range (8-12 mEq/L), indicating a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Metabolic alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increased pH (alkalosis) and increased HCO3. The patient's pH is low, not high, ruling out metabolic alkalosis.

 

Option C. Respiratory acidosis: This condition is characterized by a decreased pH (acidosis) and increased PaCO2 due to hypoventilation. The patient's PaCO2 is low, not high, ruling out respiratory acidosis.

 

Option D. Respiratory alkalosis: This condition is characterized by an increased pH (alkalosis) and decreased PaCO2 due to hyperventilation. The patient's pH is low, indicating acidosis, not alkalosis, ruling out respiratory alkalosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metabolic acidosis is indicated by a low pH and low HCO3, with the same direction of changes in both parameters. A high anion gap indicates the presence of unmeasured anions, often seen in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, and renal failure.

choices.text: Flap closure of foramen ovale
Patent ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus
Premature closure of the ductus venosus

questions.text: A 25-year primigravida is on indomethacin (25mg TDS) for polyhydramnios till 35 weeks. What abnormality can the fetus have if she goes into labor now? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Premature closure of the ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

 

Indomethacin and Fetal Effects:

 

  • Indomethacin is a non-selective cyclo-oxygenase inhibitor used in obstetrics primarily for two indications:
    • Polyhydramnios: To reduce the excessive amniotic fluid.
    • Tocolytic in preterm labor: To delay preterm labor.
  • Mechanism: Indomethacin works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins, which are important for maintaining the patency of the ductus arteriosus in the fetus.
  • Risks: When used beyond 32 weeks of gestation, indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, leading to complications such as:
    • Pulmonary hypertension
    • Right ventricular hypertrophy
    • Heart failure

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flap closure of foramen ovale: The foramen ovale normally closes soon after birth when the pressure in the left atrium exceeds the pressure in the right atrium. Indomethacin does not affect the closure of the foramen ovale.

 

Option B. Patent ductus arteriosus: Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) is a condition where the ductus arteriosus remains open after birth. Indomethacin is actually used to treat PDA by promoting its closure, not causing it.

 

Option D. Premature closure of the ductus venosus: The ductus venosus allows oxygenated blood from the umbilical vein to bypass the liver and flow directly into the inferior vena cava. Indomethacin does not influence the closure of the ductus venosus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Indomethacin can cause premature closure of the ductus arteriosus if used beyond 32 weeks of gestation.

 

Ref: Page 679, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: A person went for a trip on hills and developed difficulty breathing. He was given a diuretic which is considered as the drug of choice for this condition. What is the site of action of this drug? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PCT (Proximal Convoluted Tubule)

 

Explanation: 

 

The clinical scenario describes acute mountain sickness, characterized by breathing difficulty at high altitudes due to hypoxia. The drug of choice for both prevention and treatment of mountain sickness is acetazolamide. Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts primarily in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). It inhibits the reabsorption of bicarbonate in the PCT, causing mild metabolic acidosis which stimulates breathing and helps acclimatization to high altitude.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Thick ascending loop - Loop diuretics like furosemide act here, not acetazolamide 

 

Option C. DCT (Distal Convoluted Tubule) - Thiazide diuretics act here, not carbonic anhydrase inhibitors 

 

Option D. Collecting duct - Potassium-sparing diuretics and aldosterone antagonists act here, not carbonic anhydrase inhibitors

 

Educational Objective:

 

A carbonic anhydrase inhibitor, is the drug of choice for mountain sickness and acts in the proximal convoluted tubule.

 

Diuretics Classification Table
